headline.main: Chocolate a Health Food? Maybe, but Keep the Aspirin

docs.abstract: Researchers take keen interest in whether chocolate may lower risks of heart disease; find that chocolate and cocoa drinks contain abundant dose of flavanoids, potent antioxidants that have been found most notably in red wine, green tea and fruits and vegetables, and have been associated with decrease in risk of coronary heart disease and stroke; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Will chocolate be as intensely craved and taste as richly luscious if it is no longer viewed as a sinful treat, but, quite the contrary, a health food? Indeed, chocolate and cocoa drinks, it turns out, contain an abundant dose of flavonoids, potent antioxidants that have been found most notably in red wine, green tea and fruits and vegetables, and have been associated with a decrease in the risk of coronary heart disease and stroke. With Americans consuming chocolate at the rate of 3.3 billion pounds a year, researchers have taken a keen interest in whether chocolate may also lower risks of heart disease.
